In recent years, dysregulation of the balance between CD4 + Thomas et al., 2023 Kumar et al., 2021 Lee et al., 2020 Laragione et al., 2023 Tagkareli et al., 2022 Liu et al., 2020 H. pylori Nabavi-Rad et al., 2022 H. pylori Kedmi et al., 2022 Araújo et al., 2022 H. pylori Current research indicates potential interactions between Th17 and Treg cells, with the differentiation of both cell subsets largely relying on TGF- β Smith et al., 2013 Hang et al., 2019 β β Abbas et al., 2013 Zou and Restifo, 2010 Aarts et al., 2022 H. pylori H. pylori H. pylori H. pylori Camilo et al., 2017 β H. pylori Duan et al., 2025 H. pylori H. pylori 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Patient information The study enrolled patients diagnosed with chronic gastritis through gastroduodenoscopy and histological examination at the Affiliated Hospital of Guizhou Medical University between June 2023 and March 2024. The inclusion criteria comprised the following: (1) no use of bismuth preparations, H2-receptor antagonists, proton pump inhibitors, antibiotics, or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) within 4 weeks prior to endoscopy and (2) no history of gastric or duodenal surgery. Among 54 eligible patients, gastric mucosal biopsy specimens were evaluated using Warthin–Starry (W–S) staining, the rapid urease test (RUT), and the 14C urea breath test (14C-UBT) for group stratification. The patients were classified into the H. pylori n H. pylori n n 2.2 Main reagents and instruments The main reagents and instruments included the following: Gastric H. pylori 2.3 Specimen collection and preservation Fasting venous whole blood samples (3 mL) were collected from the patients in the morning and preserved in EDTA-anticoagulated tubes. Following centrifugation, plasma and blood cells were aseptically separated into enzyme-free EP tubes under sterile conditions. The plasma samples were stored at −80 °C, while blood cells were subjected to lymphocyte isolation using Ficoll density gradient centrifugation, followed by preservation in TRIzol reagent at −80 °C. Gastric mucosal biopsy specimens were obtained from the lesser curvature of the gastric antrum by experienced endoscopists. A portion of each sample was fixed in 10% formalin for paraffin embedding, while the remainder was immediately stored at −80 °C for subsequent experiments. 2.4 Identification of H. pylori The rapid urease test was performed by immediately placing the gastric mucosal biopsy specimens into urea enzyme reaction wells to observe color changes in the liquid medium. For hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining, the paraffin-embedded gastric mucosal sections underwent sequential processing, including routine dewaxing to hydration, nuclear staining with hematoxylin, cytoplasmic counterstaining with eosin, dehydration, and clearing, followed by mounting for microscopic examination. Warthin–Starry staining of the gastric mucosa involved processing the paraffin sections through standard dewaxing and hydration, followed by incubation with 1% silver nitrate at 60 °C for 45–60 min. The sections were then developed with a silver-gelatin solution at 60 °C for 2–5 min until a brown–black coloration appeared, followed by dehydration, clearing, and final mounting for microscopic evaluation. 2.5 Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay The plasma levels of the inflammatory factors TGF-β1, IL-10, and IL-17 were detected using their corresponding kits. The signals were detected using a spectrophotometer at 450 nm, and the ELISACalc software was used to analyze the results. 2.6 Real-time quantitative PCR A total of 100 mg of gastric mucosa tissue was lysed in 1 mL of TRIzol reagent and used to extract the total RNA. The RNA was reverse transcribed with the TaqMan reverse transcription reagent to synthesize cDNA. RT-qPCR was performed using an Opticon RT-PCR system according to the manufacturer’s instructions. mRNA levels were calculated using the 2-ΔΔCt method, with GAPDH serving as the internal reference. The primer sequences are shown in Table 1 Table 1 Sequence of the newly designed primers in the study. Target gene Primer name Sequence (5’–3’)  GAPDH Forward primer TGGCGCTGAGTACGTCG Reverse primer ACACCCATGACGAACATG  RORγt Forward primer CTGCAAGACTCATCGCCAAAG Reverse primer TTTCCACATGCTGGCTACACA  Foxp3 Forward primer ACAAGGGCTCCTGCTGCATCG Reverse primer ATGAGCGTGGCGTAGGTGAAAGG  TGF-β1 Forward primer CAGCAACAATTCCTGGCGATA Reverse primer AAGGCGAAAGCCCTCAATTT  TAK1 Forward primer CAGCCTCTGCCGCCTCCTC Reverse primer GCTCCTCTTCCAACAACCTCTTCC 2.7 Immunohistochemistry Immunohistochemical (IHC) staining was performed on 4-μm formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded gastric mucosal sections to detect the expression of TGF-β1, TAK1, p-TAK1, Foxp3, and IL-17 proteins in the gastric mucosa. After deparaffinization, the sections were incubated with primary antibodies at 4 °C overnight, washed with PBS, and incubated with secondary antibodies for 30 min, followed by additional PBS washes. The sections were developed with a DAB solution, mounted, and examined microscopically. The ImageJ color deconvolution plugin was used to measure the area fraction (percentage of positive staining area) and integrated density for all sections, with the average optical density (AOD) calculated as the ratio of integrated density to area. Throughout the experiment, identical microscope parameters and illumination conditions were maintained. The AOD values between the groups were expressed as mean ± SD, and intergroup comparisons were performed using independent samples t p 2.8 DIA proteomic analysis Gastric mucosal biopsy samples from the lesser curvature of the gastric antrum were collected from six patients in both the H. pylori H. pylori g t 2 p 2.9 Establish experimental animal models The animal study was approved by the Animal Care and Ethics Committee of Guizhou Medical University. A total of 12 C57BL/6 mice (equal gender distribution) were randomly assigned to two groups: the model group (n = 6), which received 0.5 mL of H. pylori 9 2.10 Flow cytometry Spleens from the H. pylori- H. pylori 2.11 Statistical methods Data were analyzed using the SPSS 21.0 and GraphPad Prism 5.0 software. Data that followed a normal distribution were expressed as mean ± SD. Comparisons between the two groups were performed using the independent samples t p 3 Results 3.1 Pathologic features of the gastric mucosa in H. pylori The rapid urease test revealed that the fluid surrounding the gastric mucosa turned red, indicating positive H. pylori Figure 1A H. pylori H. pylori Figure 1B H. pylori- H. pylori H. pylori- Figure 1C Figure 1 Identification of H. pylori (A) (B) H. pylori (C) Panel A compares a yellow solution indicating H. pylori negative with a red solution indicating H. pylori positive. Panel B shows histological sections; the left is H. pylori negative with orderly structures, while the right is H. pylori positive showing altered glandular architecture. Panel C presents detailed tissue sections; H. pylori negative on the left displays normal glandular structures, whereas H. pylori positive on the right shows inflammatory cell infiltration and tissue disruption. 3.2 Proteomic analysis of the gastric mucosa in the patients with H. pylori- 3.2.1 Identification of differentially expressed proteins in the gastric mucosa To better understand the potential pathogenic mechanisms of gastric mucosal inflammation following H. pylori H. pylori H. pylori Figure 2A H. pylori H. pylori Figure 2B Figure 2C Figure 2 Identification of differentially expressed proteins in the gastric mucosa. (A) (B) (C) A three-part image consisting of: A) a Venn diagram showing overlap between H. pylori negative and positive groups, with 210 (2.25%) unique to negative, 268 (2.87%) unique to positive, and 8845 (94.87%) shared; B) a volcano plot displaying significant changes in expression, with red dots indicating upregulation and blue for downregulation, compared to grey non-significant points; C) a pie chart with 95.25% CYT, 3.09% PLA, and 1.66% EXC distributions. 3.2.2 Biological information analysis of differentially expressed proteins The GO analysis of differentially expressed proteins was categorized into biological processes, cellular components, and molecular functions. The proteins were involved in biological processes, such as Th cell differentiation, positive regulation of cell differentiation, and T cell immune responses, while cellular components and molecular functions were associated with MHC class II protein complexes and receptor activity ( Figure 3A H. pylori β Figure 3B H. pylori β Figure 3C H. pylori β Table 2 H. pylori β Figure 3 Biological information analysis of differentially expressed proteins. (A) (B) (C) Panel A shows a bar graph of Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis highlighting processes like antigen processing and T-cell differentiation with varying enrichment ratios and p-values. Panel B presents a bubble chart of KEGG enrichment analysis indicating pathways like TGF-beta signaling, with colors and sizes representing adjusted p-values and numbers. Panel C displays a network diagram of protein interactions, depicting multiple nodes connected by lines, indicating relationships between proteins such as HLA and STAT1. Panel B displays bar graphs of TGF-β1 mRNA expression, significantly elevated in H. pylori positive samples for both peripheral blood and gastric mucosa. Panel C consists of immunohistochemistry images showing TGF-β1, TAK1, and p-TAK1 expression in gastric tissues, with increased staining in H. pylori positive samples, quantified by optical density in adjacent bar graphs. Panel D presents bar graphs of TAK1 mRNA expression, showing significant increases in H. pylori positive samples in both peripheral blood and gastric mucosa. 3.4 Helicobacter pylori Proteomic analysis revealed that H. pylori H. pylori Figure 5A Figure 5B H. pylori H. pylori Figure 5C Figure 5 Helicobacter pylori (A) (B) (C) n P P p t Graphs and images depict data related to *Helicobacter pylori*. Graph A shows IL-17 levels, higher in *H. pylori* positive samples. Graph B displays increased RORγt mRNA in positive samples, significant in both blood and gastric tissue. Part C includes histological images of *H. pylori* negative and positive tissues, showing more IL-17 expression in positive cases, with a bar chart confirming higher optical density for IL-17 in *H. pylori* positive tissue. Statistical significance is indicated: **P<0.01; ****P<0.0001; *P<0.05. 3.5 Helicobacter pylori During infection, Th17 and Treg contribute to the occurrence of inflammation and bacterial colonization in the gastric mucosa, with the Treg cells known to inhibit the immune response of Th17. In this study, we measured the expression levels of Treg and IL-10 using ELISA and found that the peripheral blood levels of IL-10 were significantly higher in the patients with H. pylori Figure 6A H. pylori Figure 6B H. pylori H. pylori Figure 6C Figure 6 Helicobacter pylori (A) (B) (C) n p p p t- Panel A shows a scatter plot of IL-10 levels, indicating higher values in the H. pylori positive group. Panel B features bar graphs showing increased Foxp3 mRNA levels in both peripheral blood and gastric mucosa for H. pylori positive samples. Panel C includes microscopic images comparing Foxp3 expression in H. pylori negative and positive tissues, with higher expression in the positive, as confirmed by an optical density bar graph. Statistical significance is indicated by asterisks. 3.6 Helicobacter pylori The elevated expression of RORγt and Foxp3 mRNA in the gastric mucosa and peripheral blood, as well as the increased expression of Th17 and Treg in the gastric mucosa, of the patients with infectious gastritis indicated that Th17 and Treg responses play crucial roles in antimicrobial immunity during H. pylori H. pylori Figure 7A H. pylori-infected Figure 7B H. pylori H. pylori Figure 7 Helicobacter pylori (A) (B) n p p t Flow cytometry analysis comparing control and model groups for Th17 and Treg cells. Panel A shows dot plots and bar graphs for CD4+IL-17+Th17 cells, with no significant difference between groups. Panel B displays bar graphs for the Th17/Treg ratio, showing a significant decrease in the model group, indicated by an asterisk. Lower plots show CD4+CD25+Foxp3+Treg cells, with a significant increase in the model group, denoted by three asterisks. 4 Discussion Helicobacter pylori H. pylori H. pylori Yin et al., 2025 Kalisperati et al., 2017 H. pylori The inflammatory and immune responses during H. pylori H. pylori Brackman et al., 2024 Raghavan and Quiding-Järbrink, 2012 Sehrawat et al., 2015 β Wang et al., 2023 β Aarts et al., 2022 H. pylori β H. pylori H. pylori β H. pylori H. pylori Proteomic analysis of gastric mucosal tissues revealed that differentially expressed proteins during H. pylori β H. pylori H. pylori H. pylori β Li et al., 2015 Altobelli et al., 2019 β H. pylori β H. pylori H. pylori Das et al., 2021 Eichhorn et al., 2012 He et al., 2016 H. pylori The MAPK and TGF- β β Chu et al., 2024 Dong et al., 2020 Ren et al., 2020 Zhao et al., 2021 H. pylori Hayakawa et al., 2013 H. pylori β H. pylori TGF-β exhibits pleiotropic functions in Treg and Th17 cell biology, promoting Foxp3 expression to drive Treg cell generation while suppressing Th17 differentiation ( Schnell et al., 2021 Wu et al., 2025 van der Veeken et al., 2022 H. pylori + Sun et al., 2022 Lee et al., 2020 H. pylori H. pylori Our animal model experiments revealed Th17/Treg imbalance in mice with H. pylori H. pylori Cui et al., 2024 H. pylori In summary, this study provides preliminary evidence of significant upregulation of TGF-β1/TAK1 proteins in the gastric tissues of adult patients with H. pylori H. pylori H. pylori We thank the patients who participated in this study and provided the samples, as well as the Digestive Endoscopy Center and Pathology Department of the Affiliated Hospital of Guizhou Medical University for their assistance.
